history.content:
Took EE122 last spring. Has no programming assignments (except a project, where you can choose the language of coding and the project itself). The theory of networking including queuing models is what the course is about. The textbook is a difficult read, but comprehensive. The homework problems can be hard, make you think. From what I have seen of CS168 from the public material, EE122 can be complementary to 168. 168 is a lot of hands-on practical network programming (Python I believe), EE122 is more theoretical concepts / networking algo / research type.

----------

I have never taken EE122 but I am a current TA for CS168 and would have to heavily disagree that CS168 is a lot of hands-on practical network programming beyond the projects which are inherently hands-on and practical as well as disconnected from the rest of the course in some ways. I am biased but I think that this classification is an injustice to the class. The class definitely teaches you the understanding of the current protocols and architecture so one could boil it down to such at a glance but in reality, these are only taught because they are expected out of such a class. Scott, who teaches it almost exclusively, tries to focus heavily on theoretical underpinnings and challenges that come with networking and then uses the current protocols and architecture as case studies on what fundamental challenges people were solving as well as some fundamental flaws in the design that may or may not be solvable as well. If you are interested in understanding the internet, I would definitely take this class. at the most basic level, CS168 is a design and architecture class and EE122, from what I know, is an engineering and systems class. If you are specifically interested in an understanding of the internet architecture and design, CS168 should be provide you with the fundamentals. if you also want an engineering perspective on networking, take EE122.

Took EE122 last spring. Has no programming assignments (except a project, where you can choose the language of coding and the project itself). The theory of networking including queuing models is what the course is about. The textbook is a difficult read, but comprehensive. The homework problems can be hard, make you think. From what I have seen of CS168 from the public material, EE122 can be complementary to 168. 168 is a lot of hands-on practical network programming (Python I believe), EE122 is more theoretical concepts / networking algo / research type.

I am a cs major interested in network, specifically Internet. Since cs168 isn't offered next semester, I'm planning to take ee122 instead. However, I heard that ee122 isn't necessary and taking 168 is more applicable to a cs major. Should I wait and take cs 168/ take both?/take ee122 this semester?

Any input is greatly appreciated!!!
history.subject: ee 122
